title: CanEpiRisk
text: Quantifying cancer risks associated ionizing radiation central radiation epidemiology public health, especially estimating lifetime risks across populations exposure scenarios. CanEpiRisk provides integrated R framework : () import exposure demographic inputs, (ii) specify risk models—excess relative rate (ERR) excess absolute rate (EAR)—(iii) compute key measures including cumulative excess risk (CER) years life lost (YLL). package streamlines end--end risk assessment, improves reproducibility, enables transparent comparisons across models, populations, exposure profiles.

title: CanEpiRisk
text: Define exposure scenario (ages exposure, doses, sex). Select reference data (site-specific baseline + -cause mortality). Choose risk model (model appropriate outcome/site). Set options (e.g., follow-max age, weighting ERR vs EAR, Monte Carlo sampling, … etc.). Compute CER / YLL summarize.

title: CanEpiRisk
text: Notes. sex: commonly 1 = male, 2 = female. Region indices follow package’s regional ordering. maxage: Upper bound attained age lifetime accumulation. err_wgt: value 0 1 (inclusive; 1 = pure ERR; 0 = pure EAR). n_mcsamp: Monte Carlo samples (default=10,000). Comparing Scenarios
code: set.seed(100)     # for reproducibility  ## Example 1: CER for all solid cancer mortality ## Region 1, female (sex = 2), 0.1 Gy at age 15, follow to age 100; LSS linear ERR exp1 <- list(agex = 15, doseGy = 0.1, sex = 2)   # exposure scenario ref1 <- list(   baseline  = Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,          # site-specific baseline   mortality = Mortality[[1]]$allcause           # all-cause mortality ) mod1 <- LSS_mortality$allsolid$L                # risk model (linear ERR) opt1 <- list(maxage = 100, err_wgt = 1, n_mcsamp = 10000)  cer1 <- CER(exposure = exp1, reference = ref1, riskmodel = mod1, option = opt1) cer1_per10k <- cer1 * 10000 cer1_per10k ## Example 2: CER for leukaemia incidence ## Region 4, male (sex = 1), 100 mGy total delivered evenly from age 30–45, ## follow to age 60; LSS LQ EAR exp2 <- list(agex = 30:44 + 0.5, doseGy = rep(0.1/15, 15), sex = 1) ref2 <- list(   baseline  = Incidence[[4]]$leukaemia,         # site-specific baseline   mortality = Mortality[[4]]$allcause           # all-cause mortality rates ) mod2 <- LSS_incidence$leukaemia$LQ              # risk model (LQ EAR) opt2 <- list(maxage = 60, err_wgt = 0, n_mcsamp = 10000)  cer2 <- CER(exposure = exp2, reference = ref2, riskmodel = mod2, option = opt2) cer2_per10k <- cer2 * 10000 cer2_per10k scenario_grid <- data.frame(   doseGy = c(0.05, 0.1, 0.2),   agex   = c(15, 30, 45) )  compareCER <- function(doseGy, agex) {   exp <- list(agex = agex, doseGy = doseGy, sex = 2)   CER(exposure = exp, reference = ref1, riskmodel = mod1, option = opt1) * 10000 }  CER_per10k <- t( mapply(compareCER, scenario_grid$doseGy, scenario_grid$agex) ) cbind( scenario_grid, CER_per10k )

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
text: CanEpiRisk supports two ways supply risk models lifetime risk (CER, YLL) related computations: LSS_mortality (mortality) LSS_incidence (incidence) para: numeric vector parameter estimates var: variance–covariance matrix para f(beta, data, lag): function returning ERR/EAR given parameters beta, data frame, minimum latency lag predefined models cover standard ERR (excess relative rate) EAR (excess absolute rate) formulations multiple cancer sites. typical data fields expected model functions : dose (e.g., Gy), age (attained age), agex (age exposure), sex (1 = male, 2 = female). Notes - Use lag enforce minimum latency exposure attained age (e.g., 5 y solid cancers, 2 y leukaemia). - Model objects organized site dose–response form (e.g., L = linear, LQ = linear–quadratic), err /ear entries.

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
text: can define model endpoint supplying list required components. template linear ERR model using common covariates; adapt needed. Tip: Keep parameter order para consistent index inside f().
code: my_err_fun <- function(beta, data, lag = 5) {   # beta: parameter vector   # data: data.frame with columns dose, age, agex, sex (1=male, 2=female)   # lag : minimum latency (years)   # Example linear in dose with modifiers:   out <- exp(beta[1]) * data$dose *          exp(beta[2] * (data$agex - 30) / 10 + beta[3] * log(data$age / 70)) *          (1 + c(-1, 1)[data$sex] * beta[4]) *          (data$age - data$agex >= lag)   return(out) }  my_model <- list(   para = c(-0.86, -0.35, -0.86, 0.34),   # example values   var  = diag(c(0.01, 0.01, 0.18, 0.008)),# example diagonal VCOV   err  = list(para = c(-0.86, -0.35, -0.86, 0.34),               var  = diag(c(0.01, 0.01, 0.18, 0.008)),               f    = my_err_fun)   # optionally: ear = list(para=..., var=..., f=...) )

title: Calculate Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to Radiation Exposure — YLL
text: Computes expected Years Life Lost (YLL) attributable radiation exposure. function integrates site-specific baseline mortality -cause mortality rates user-specified excess risk models (ERR/EAR) estimate expected reduction life expectancy due radiation-attributable cancer mortality. function supports single-age protracted exposure scenarios allows uncertainty quantification via Monte Carlo sampling.

title: Calculate Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to Radiation Exposure — YLL
text: exposure list specifying exposure scenario: agex — age(s) exposure (scalar numeric vector). doseGy — dose(s) Gray (Gy), scalar vector length agex. sex — sex indicator (1 = male, 2 = female). reference list specifying baseline -cause mortality information: baseline — data.frame site-specific mortality (incidence) rates per person-year, including columns age, male, female. mortality — data.frame -cause mortality rates (per person-year) structure age range baseline. correspond population region. riskmodel list defining excess risk model, typically form: err /ear — sublists containing: para — vector model parameters. var — variance–covariance matrix parameters (multi-parameter models). ci — 95% confidence bounds single-parameter model (alternative var). f(beta, data, lag) — function returning age-specific excess risks. option list optional settings: maxage — maximum attained age accumulation (default: 100). err_wgt — weight ERR (1) EAR (0) transfer models. n_mcsamp — number Monte Carlo draws uncertainty estimation (default: 10,000). alpha — significance level confidence intervals (default: 0.05).

title: Calculate Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to Radiation Exposure — YLL
text: named numeric vector point interval summaries cumulative excess risk, typically including: mle: point estimate, mean, median: Monte Carlo summaries, ci_lo, ci_up: confidence interval. Values per person; multiply 1e4 1e5 report per 10,000 100,000.

title: Calculate Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to Radiation Exposure — YLL
text: YLL estimate integrates excess mortality age, weighted remaining life expectancy, producing interpretable measure life expectancy loss attributable radiation. computation uses region- sex-specific mortality data provided package supplied user. Typical usage involves pairing YLL() CER() population_YLL() complementary assessments probability-based life loss–based risk metrics.
